image.altText: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers the 2024/25 Budget.

props.synopsis: The treasurer hands down his third budget, with a raft of measures aimed to deal with Australia's cost-of-living crisis. Follow live.

title.children: Jim Chalmers says top priority is to help Australians with cost of living

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: What's the deal with the $300 energy bill relief?
Forgotten what the revised Stage 3 tax cuts look like? Here's a refresher
Why will high earning Australians get $300 for energy bills?

image.altText: Convicted child sex offender Allan Hopkins.

props.synopsis: A convicted child rapist wanted for new alleged child sex offences in South Australia is sentenced to at least seven months in jail for theft and driving crimes in another state.

title.children: Convicted paedophile Allan John Hopkins jailed for other crimes after national manhunt

image.altText: A tight shot of the 2024/2025 federal budget.

props.synopsis: A $300 energy bill credit for every household, a 10 per cent increase to Commonwealth rent assistance and capped PBS medicine prices headline a budget aimed at easing living costs and bolstering the government's pre-election standing.

title.children: Every household to get $300 credit for energy bills as government vows move will reduce inflation

image.altText: Collage of scrabble letters W + L with blue and red backgrounds and icon illustrations.

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has handed down the government's third budget. Have a look at what's new — and what's in it for you.

title.children: Who are the winners and losers in this year's budget?

image.altText: A young woman wearing jeans and a white T-shirt leading a horse wearing a rug

props.synopsis: Poppy Crozier's life was cut short when she was was killed in a three-vehicle crash on the Dukes Highway. Her family have confronted the driver responsible in court.

title.children: Grieving family says young woman killed in car crash had 'incredible potential that she will never fulfil'

image.altText: Jim Chalmers smiles behind a desk with a laptop.

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says helping Australians with the cost of living is the government's number one priority. So what's actually in the budget for households feeling the pinch?

title.children: From cheaper medicines to energy bill rebates, a three-minute guide to cost-of-living relief in the budget

image.altText: Collage of Jim Chalmers and Anthony Albanese in black and white, with map of Australia in background.

props.synopsis: This federal budget doesn't read like one where the cabinet put a list together of disgruntled people to appease — instead, it acknowledges the government is facing a mountain of problems that cannot be solved any time soon.

title.children: Much of Chalmers's success will rest on just one budget measure that economists will hate

image.altText: SunDrive CEO Vince Allen holds a small solar panel featuring the company's new technology.

props.synopsis: The Albanese government is spending big on its ambition to engineer a "Future Made in Australia", while leaving some scraps for small businesses struggling with the here and now.

title.children: What's in the budget for businesses? A lot, for those who can engineer a 'Future Made in Australia'

image.altText: Australian shepherd dogs behind a cage with one dog looing through a hole in the fence.

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has moved to impose tougher penalties for dog attacks under proposed reforms to the state's Dog and Cat Management Act.

title.children: Penalties for 'vicious' dog attacks to be strengthened in SA under proposed law reforms

image.altText: A futuristic building surrounded by trees and landscaped gardens.

props.synopsis: Adelaide's planned Tarrkarri Centre for First Nations Cultures is dealt a further blow, with a request for more federal government funding expected to be knocked back.

title.children: No extra federal cash for Adelaide's stalled First Nations cultural centre

image.altText: Dramatic storm clouds over ocean in Flinders in Victoria land peninsula in bottom right-hand side

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology's declaration means there is a 50 per cent chance of the eastern Pacific cool phase developing later this year. It would make it the fourth La Niña in just five years.

title.children: BOM moves to 'La Niña watch' as ocean heat at record high for a year straight

image.altText: David speaks into a microphone as supporters' signs wave behind him and a guy holds a guitar.

props.synopsis: Former military lawyer David McBride is jailed for unlawfully leaking classified documents to journalists after last year pleading guilty to stealing and sharing secret military information.

title.children: Former military lawyer David McBride jailed for sharing classified information with journalists

image.altText: A newborn baby peeps over a woman's shoulder.

props.synopsis: The federal budget measure — slated to begin in July next year — is a $1.1 billion promise over four years to help improve the retirement outcomes for working mothers.

title.children: Budget confirms $1.1 billion spend to add super to paid parental leave

image.altText: Chalmers laughing at press conference

props.synopsis: The Albanese government is getting back into business, literally. But will its bets on a Future Made in Australia pay off?

title.children: Is this the end of small government?

image.altText: Michelle Bullock speaking and gesturing with her hands while giving a speech.

props.synopsis: Economists are likely to quibble with the government's claim its budget is helping, not hindering, the inflation fight, but in the end the RBA's judgment will be what matters.

title.children: The government is promising an inflation fix by Christmas, but will the RBA believe it?

image.altText: A close up of Greg Lynn standing in front of a body of water near some rocks.

props.synopsis: Greg Lynn admits covering up the deaths of two campers and disposing of their bodies, his lawyer says, but insists he is innocent of murder.

title.children: 'Two accidental deaths': Lawyers for ex-pilot Greg Lynn outline defence case in camper murder trial

image.altText: Brett Allford wearing a black hat and black sunglasses

props.synopsis: A teenager describes the ongoing trauma she lives with as a result of the offending of Brett Daniel Allford who had worked for both the South Australian Cricket Association and the South Australian National Football League as an umpire.

title.children: 'Sometimes I see his face': Teenager delivers powerful victim impact statement to former umpire

image.altText: Two hands holding a latte in a black cup and saucer.

props.synopsis: Have you changed your coffee habits? One market expert says while the morning cafe cuppa continues, those on tight budgets are adding instant options to the mix later in the day.

title.children: Cafes feel the pinch as cash-strapped coffee drinkers look to instant alternatives

image.altText: Teenagers use their phones.

props.synopsis: Children under 14 could be banned from having social media accounts in South Australia, with a review now underway. Here's a look at what is being proposed.

title.children: One Australian state wants to impose a social media ban for under 14s, but how would it work?

image.altText: A ute bogged in the outback.

props.synopsis: Carl Jakeway and his wife did their best to get themselves out of trouble, but eventually activated their locator beacon and were rescued by police.

title.children: Couple ration water, stockpile urine after car bogs on remote outback track

image.altText: Rachel (fair right) pictured with two of her daughters, wearing white and orange dresses, hugging each other.

props.synopsis: As the cost-of-living crisis worsens, the ABC spoke to families and students who say they're relying on savings tip-offs online, discount stores, and food banks to get by.

title.children: Rachel 'hit the jackpot' when she found meat for 74 cents. She posted the bargain online to help others deal with rising costs

image.altText: CCTV car at night

props.synopsis: Police have launched a homicide investigation after CCTV vision emerged of a suspected car chase leading up to a crash that killed four people in northern NSW.

title.children: Fatal car crash now a homicide investigation as grieving families plead for mystery driver to come forward

image.altText: A wide shot of the front of the Supreme Court of WA with a garden bed in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A WA mother accused of attempting to murder her severely disabled daughter by injecting her with insulin tells a Perth jury her intention was only to get the child into hospital for treatment.

title.children: Trial of mother accused of attempting to murder daughter with insulin hears she was trying to get her into hospital

image.altText: Toutai Kefu arrives at the Supreme Court of Queensland in Brisbane.

props.synopsis: The teens who violently attacked rugby union great Toutai Kefu and his family inside their Brisbane home were drunk and confused, but Mr Kefu's wife vividly replays the nightmarish night and can not erase the images, a Brisbane court hears.

title.children: Teens who attacked Toutai Kefu and his family should be jailed for 10 years, a court hears

image.altText: A large sign that says 'you are now entering free gaza encampment' with a few tents in the background and a Palestine flag.

props.synopsis: Tensions over pro-Palestinian encampments and protests at Australian universities are in the spotlight, with one Melbourne university ordering participants to dismantle their camp, and the prime minister weighing in on a demonstration at another.

title.children: Students ordered to dismantle pro-Palestinian encampment as tensions flare over university protests

image.altText: Ocean Race

props.synopsis: A group of at least 15 orcas off the coast of Spain have sunk seven boats over the past four years. The origin of this new behaviour has baffled scientists, though the leading theory suggests they're following a "social fad".

title.children: Orcas have sunk another boat off European coast. Baffled scientists think they may know why

image.altText: A Collingwood fan hugs West Coast's Harvey Johnston

props.synopsis: A Collingwood fan will not be able to watch his side in action for the rest of the season after the AFL came down hard on him for grabbing West Coast's Harvey Johnston.

title.children: Collingwood fan left 'a broken man' after AFL bans him for grabbing West Coast's Harvey Johnston

image.altText: Petrol station

props.synopsis: Officials say the agency that owns the billboard did not have a permit to put up the hoarding, measuring larger than an olympic swimming pool.

title.children: Fourteen dead, more than 70 injured after storm brings down massive Mumbai billboard

image.altText: plane on tarmac with man walking down

props.synopsis: Bonza workers are told they will remain stood down for at least another two weeks, as administrators scramble to find investors to support the troubled airline.

title.children: 'Grim' mood among Bonza staff facing two months without pay

image.altText: a young girl smiling and holding an umbrella

props.synopsis: The grandfather of Charlise Mutten has told court of his granddaughter's unconditional love for her mother and her question about whether her accused killer would make a good father.

title.children: Charlise Mutten asked grandfather if alleged killer would make 'good father', court told

image.altText: This photograph shows a view of burnt cars and a burnt Renault car shop amid protests in New Caledonia.

props.synopsis: Overnight riots in the South Pacific French territory saw vehicles torched and roads blocked in the wake of proposed constitutional reforms.

title.children: New Caledonia imposes curfew following fiery overnight riots

image.altText: A composite image of David Shoebridge, James Paterson and Peter Khalil.

props.synopsis: Chinese police hunting international corruption targets were allowed into Australia by the federal police and subsequently escorted a woman back to China for trial, in a major breach of Chinese-Australian police protocols.

title.children: 'Extrajudicial extradition': MPs alarmed about Chinese police escorting Australian resident to China for trial

image.altText: A child scrolls through a tablet.

props.synopsis: The timing of South Australia's announcement of a social media ban suggests that the federal government's plan to introduce age verification for porn could easily be expanded — and is it any surprise?

title.children: First porn, then social media? How age verification tech could cross over

image.altText: A young white woman with long fair hair standing in a field. She is wearing a green cardigan

props.synopsis: Dozens of patients have contacted the ABC, reporting alarming side effects including vomiting blood and permanent tingling in their fingers after taking replica weight loss drugs.

title.children: Ilisa was vomiting blood after injecting replica Ozempic. The pharmacy kept ringing to sell her more

image.altText: Explosions go off on a damaged section of bridge, which is leaning against a damaged cargo ship

props.synopsis: The controlled demolition marks a major step in freeing the container ship Dali, which has been stuck amid the wreckage since it lost power and crashed into one of the bridge's support columns shortly after leaving Baltimore on March 26.

title.children: 'Surgical' demolition brings down largest remaining section of Baltimore bridge
